subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text: Possibly borrowed from the linguistic ancestor of {{cog|hmx-pro|*glaau³ᴬ}} ({{zh-ref|Bodman 1980}}, {{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}). The oldest-known domesticated peach stones so far have been excavated in [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4156326/ Zhejiang], east of the {{w|Zhongyuan|Central Plain}} cradle of Chinese civilization.

subSections.title: Compounds
Etymology
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|もも}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=もも}}. Brought to Japan in antiquity, with pits found in prehistoric sites from the {{w|Yayoi period}}, 300 BCE - 300 CE. Mentioned as a [[food]] in documents from the {{w|Nara period|Nara}} and {{w|Heian period|Heian}} periods.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

Ultimate derivation unknown. Theories include the following.
* Possibly derived originally from a reduplication of {{m|ja|実|tr={{upright|Old Japanese}} mu, {{upright|modern Japanese}} mi||fruit}}, from the way that peaches often grow in clusters. However, the vowel shift seems unlikely given regular Japanese phonetic shifts. In addition, most reduplicated terms in Japanese have the {{m|ja|頭高型|tr=atamadaka-gata}} pitch accent pattern, starting high and falling, which differs from the {{m|ja|平板型|tr=heiban-gata}} pitch accent pattern of this term.
* Possibly cognate with {{cog|ojp|-}} {{m|ja|百|tr=momo||hundred; lots}}. However, this also has the {{m|ja|頭高型|tr=atamadaka-gata}} pitch accent pattern.
* Possibly a reduplication of {{m|ja|毛|tr=mo||hair}}, from the way that peaches are [[hairy]]. The term is spelled as {{lang|ja|毛毛}} in some ancient documents. However, {{m|ja|毛}} was commonly used as [[man'yōgana]] for its phonetic value, in which cases its original Chinese meaning of {{m|en|hair}} is usually ignored.
None of the above possibilities seems very compelling. Given the archaeological evidence, this term probably originated before the Japanese ancestor population migrated to the Japanese [[archipelago]].

Possibly related to {{m|ja|梅|tr={{upright|ancient}} mume, {{upright|modern}} ume||Japanese apricot, Japanese plum}}.
